title: Understanding Health Insurance
description: Learn how health insurance works, understand your plan, and navigate the insurance system to get the coverage you deserve.

content.overview: Health insurance helps pay for medical care. Understanding the different types helps you choose the right coverage.

main_insurance_types.description: Health insurance provided through your job
main_insurance_types.how_it_works: Your employer chooses the insurance company and plan options. You may choose from several plans. The cost is usually shared between you and your employer.
pros: Employer pays part of the cost
cons: Lose coverage if you leave the job

main_insurance_types.description: Insurance you buy through Healthcare.gov or state marketplace
main_insurance_types.how_it_works: You shop for plans during open enrollment. Subsidies may lower your cost based on income.
pros: Financial help available based on income
Cannot be denied for pre-existing conditions

main_insurance_types.description: Federal insurance for people 65+ or with certain disabilities
main_insurance_types.who_qualifies: People 65 and older, younger people with disabilities, people with end-stage renal disease

parts.Part A: Hospital coverage (usually free if you worked 10+ years)
parts.Part B: Doctor visits and outpatient care (monthly premium)
parts.Part C: Medicare Advantage - private plans covering A, B, and often D

main_insurance_types.description: State and federal program for low-income individuals
main_insurance_types.who_qualifies: Based on income and family size - varies by state
main_insurance_types.coverage: Comprehensive coverage with little or no cost to you

main_insurance_types.who_qualifies: Children in families with income too high for Medicaid but cannot afford private insurance
main_insurance_types.coverage: Comprehensive coverage for children at low cost

content.key_point: The best insurance for you depends on your situation - age, income, employment, and health needs

content.overview: Health plans organize healthcare delivery in different ways. Each type balances flexibility with cost differently.

plan_types.how_it_works: You choose a primary care doctor who coordinates your care. You must use in-network providers except for emergencies.
plan_types.cost: Usually lower premiums and out-of-pocket costs
plan_types.best_for: People who want lower costs and do not mind needing referrals

plan_types.how_it_works: You can see any doctor but pay less for in-network providers. No primary care doctor required.
plan_types.best_for: People who want flexibility to choose their own doctors

plan_types.how_it_works: Like a PPO but only covers in-network care except emergencies
plan_types.cost: Lower than PPO, similar to HMO
plan_types.best_for: People who want flexibility without referrals but can stay in-network

plan_types.how_it_works: Combines HMO and PPO features. You have a primary care doctor but can see out-of-network providers at higher cost.
plan_types.best_for: People who want a primary care doctor but also some flexibility

plan_types.how_it_works: Lower monthly premiums but higher deductibles. Often paired with a Health Savings Account (HSA).
plan_types.cost: Lowest premiums but highest out-of-pocket until deductible met
plan_types.best_for: Healthy people who want lower premiums and can save in an HSA

metal_levels.description: Marketplace plans are categorized by how costs are shared

levels.best_for: Healthy people who rarely need care
Average healthcare users; qualifies for cost-sharing reductions if income eligible

sections.title: Understanding Costs: Deductibles, Copays, and Coinsurance

content.overview: Health insurance involves several different types of costs. Understanding each helps you budget for healthcare.

cost_types.definition: The amount you pay each month to have insurance
details: You pay this whether you use healthcare or not
May be deducted from paycheck for employer plans
cost_types.example: You pay $400 per month for your health insurance

cost_types.definition: The amount you pay for care before insurance starts paying
details: Some services (like preventive care) may be covered before deductible
Family plans may have individual and family deductibles
cost_types.example: With a $1,500 deductible, you pay the first $1,500 of covered services, then insurance starts sharing costs

cost_types.definition: A fixed amount you pay for a service
details: Usually applies after deductible is met
Some plans have copays before deductible for certain services
cost_types.example: You pay $25 for each primary care visit, $50 for specialists

cost_types.definition: Your percentage of the cost after deductible is met
details: You and insurance share costs as a percentage
Applies until you reach out-of-pocket maximum
cost_types.example: With 20% coinsurance, you pay $200 of a $1,000 bill and insurance pays $800

cost_types.definition: The most you pay in a year for covered services
details: Does not include premiums or out-of-network costs
cost_types.example: With a $6,000 out-of-pocket max, once you have paid $6,000 in covered costs, your insurance pays everything else for the year

how_costs_work_together.scenario: You have a plan with a $1,000 deductible, $30 copay for doctor visits, 20% coinsurance, and $6,000 out-of-pocket maximum
example: January: You visit urgent care - you pay full $200 (toward deductible)
March: Lab work costs $400 - you pay full $400 (toward deductible)
May: Surgery costs $15,000 - you pay remaining $400 of deductible plus 20% of the rest ($2,920) = $3,320
At this point you have paid $3,920 total toward your $6,000 max
Rest of year: You pay 20% of costs until reaching $6,000, then insurance pays 100%

tips_for_managing_costs: Compare total costs (premium + expected out-of-pocket) when choosing plans
Use preventive care - it is usually free before deductible
Ask for cost estimates before procedures
Use an HSA or FSA for tax-free medical savings

content.overview: Prior authorization is approval from your insurance company before you get certain services or medications. Without it, your insurance may not pay.

what_is_prior_authorization.definition: Insurance company approval required before certain healthcare services are covered
what_is_prior_authorization.purpose: Insurance companies use it to ensure services are medically necessary and appropriate

services_that_may_require_prior_auth: MRI, CT scan, and other advanced imaging
Physical therapy beyond a certain number of visits

the_process.action: Submits request to insurance with documentation of medical necessity
Reviews request (usually within days to weeks)
Approves, denies, or requests more information

timeframes.medications: May be faster through pharmacy channels

options: Ask why - the denial letter must explain the reason
Provide additional documentation of medical necessity
Request a peer-to-peer review (your doctor talks to insurance doctor)

your_responsibilities: Ask if prior authorization is needed before scheduling procedures
Confirm the authorization is in place before your appointment
Keep copies of authorization approval letters
Know your authorization is valid for a specific time period
Understand that authorization does not guarantee full payment

common_problems.solution: Follow up with your doctor's office and insurance; ask for urgent review if medically necessary
Reschedule or risk paying the full cost yourself
Contact your doctor to submit corrected request
Request a new authorization before proceeding

step_therapy.definition: Insurance requires you try cheaper treatments first before covering expensive ones
step_therapy.example: Must try generic medication before brand-name is covered
step_therapy.exception_process: Your doctor can request an exception if cheaper option is not appropriate for you

content.overview: If your insurance denies coverage for a service or medication, you have the right to appeal. Many appeals are successful.
your_rights: Every denial comes with appeal rights
You must receive a written explanation of why coverage was denied
You have specific timeframes to file appeals (usually 30-180 days)
You can have someone (like your doctor) appeal on your behalf

types_of_denials.meaning: Insurance says the service is not needed for your condition
types_of_denials.appeal_strategy: Get detailed letter from doctor explaining why it is necessary for you specifically

types_of_denials.meaning: Service is excluded from your plan
types_of_denials.appeal_strategy: Harder to overturn, but may argue medical necessity or that alternative would cost more

types_of_denials.meaning: Insurance considers the treatment not proven
types_of_denials.appeal_strategy: Provide research studies and expert opinions supporting the treatment

types_of_denials.meaning: Provider is not in your plan's network
types_of_denials.appeal_strategy: Show no in-network provider can provide the care or that you were not informed

types_of_denials.meaning: Required approval was not gotten before service
types_of_denials.appeal_strategy: Show it was an emergency or that you were not informed PA was needed

appeal_levels.who_reviews: Different person at your insurance company
appeal_levels.timeframe: Usually 30-60 days for standard; 72 hours for urgent
tips: Include all medical records supporting your case
Get a letter from your doctor explaining medical necessity
Reference your plan documents and any coverage policies
Be specific about why the denial was wrong

appeal_levels.when: If first internal appeal is denied (some states require this step)
appeal_levels.tips: Add new evidence or arguments not in first appeal

appeal_levels.who_reviews: Independent third party outside your insurance company
appeal_levels.important: Decision is binding on the insurance company
tips: This is your most powerful tool
External reviewers often overturn insurance denials
Include all documentation from previous appeals

what_to_include_in_appeal: Your name, policy number, and claim number
The specific denial you are appealing
Why you believe the denial is wrong
Letter from your doctor explaining medical necessity
Clinical guidelines or research supporting the treatment
How the condition affects your daily life
What happens if you do not get this treatment

urgent_appeals.when_to_use: Treatment delay would seriously jeopardize your health
urgent_appeals.how_to_request: Ask your doctor to call and request urgent/expedited review

getting_help.patient_advocate: Your hospital or doctor's office may help with appeals
getting_help.state_insurance_department: Can help with appeals and complaints
getting_help.legal_aid: Free legal help for low-income individuals
getting_help.patient_advocacy_organizations: Disease-specific groups often help with appeals

success_rates.fact: About 50% of appeals are successful, but most people never appeal
success_rates.implication: Always appeal if you believe coverage was wrongly denied

content.overview: Medicare is federal health insurance for people 65 and older and some younger people with disabilities. Understanding its parts helps you make the most of your coverage.
who_qualifies: People 65 and older who are U.S. citizens or permanent residents
People under 65 with certain disabilities (after 24 months of Social Security disability)
People with End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD) or ALS

medicare_parts.cost: Usually free if you or spouse worked 10+ years and paid Medicare taxes
Monthly premium ($174.70 standard in 2024, higher for higher incomes)

medicare_parts.what_it_is: Private insurance plans that include Part A and Part B coverage
medicare_parts.how_it_works: You get all Medicare benefits through one private plan
medicare_parts.cost: May have $0 premium plans; different cost-sharing than Original Medicare

medicare_parts.how_to_get: Enroll in standalone Part D plan or Medicare Advantage plan with drug coverage
medicare_parts.cost: Monthly premium varies by plan; deductible up to $545 (2024)
medicare_parts.donut_hole: Coverage gap where you pay more, then catastrophic coverage kicks in

medigap.what_it_is: Supplemental insurance to cover costs Original Medicare does not pay
medigap.standardized_plans: Plans A through N offer different levels of coverage
medigap.when_to_buy: Best rates during 6-month open enrollment after Part B starts

enrollment_periods.general_enrollment: January 1 - March 31 each year (for Part A and B)
enrollment_periods.annual_enrollment: October 15 - December 7 (to change Part C or D plans)
enrollment_periods.special_enrollment: When you have qualifying life events

late_enrollment_penalties.part_b: 10% higher premiums for each year you could have had Part B but did not
late_enrollment_penalties.part_d: 1% higher premiums for each month you could have had Part D but did not
late_enrollment_penalties.avoiding_penalties: Enroll when first eligible unless you have other creditable coverage

extra_help.what_it_is: Program to help pay Medicare prescription drug costs
extra_help.benefits: Help with Part D premiums, deductibles, and copays

content.overview: Medicaid provides health coverage to millions of Americans with limited income. It is jointly funded by states and the federal government, with each state running its own program.

income_limits.expansion_states: Adults may qualify with income up to 138% of federal poverty level
income_limits.non_expansion_states: Generally must be in a covered category (pregnant, disabled, parent, etc.)
income_limits.children: Often qualify at higher income levels than adults (through CHIP if not Medicaid)

what_medicaid_covers.for_children: Comprehensive coverage including dental, vision, and developmental services (EPSDT)

cost.premiums: Most states charge no premium or very low premiums
cost.copays: Little to no copays in most states
cost.no_cost_groups: No cost-sharing for children, pregnant women, and some other groups

how_to_apply: Through Healthcare.gov (you may be directed to Medicaid)
At hospitals (they can help you apply)

medicaid_and_medicare.dual_eligibility: Some people qualify for both Medicare and Medicaid
dual_eligible_benefits: Medicaid may cover services Medicare does not (like dental, vision)
medicaid_and_medicare.medi_medi: Programs vary by state for people with both Medicare and Medicaid

medicaid_managed_care.what_it_is: Most states have Medicaid beneficiaries enroll in managed care plans
medicaid_managed_care.how_it_works: You choose a health plan and get care through that plan's network

important_rules.retroactive_coverage: Medicaid can cover bills from up to 3 months before you applied
important_rules.estate_recovery: States may seek repayment from your estate for long-term care costs after death
important_rules.continuous_eligibility: Some states provide 12-month continuous coverage regardless of income changes

content.overview: Complex insurance situations require understanding advanced rules and strategies for managing coverage.

coordination_of_benefits.definition: Rules for how multiple insurance plans pay for care
coordination_of_benefits.primary_vs_secondary: Primary insurance pays first, secondary pays some or all of remaining costs
coordination_of_benefits.birthday_rule: For children with two working parents, the parent whose birthday comes first in the year is primary

medicare_secondary: If you have employer coverage through current employment
For first 30 months of Medicare due to disability
For first 30 months after ESRD diagnosis
medicare_primary: If employer has fewer than 20 employees

cobra.definition: Law allowing you to keep employer insurance after leaving a job
cobra.duration: Usually 18 months (36 months in some circumstances)
cobra.cost: You pay full premium plus 2% administrative fee
cobra.deadline: Must elect within 60 days of qualifying event
considerations: Expensive but allows continuity of care
Marketplace may offer subsidies COBRA does not

special_enrollment_periods.what_they_are: Times you can enroll in or change insurance outside open enrollment

when_to_request: No in-network provider can treat your condition
In-network provider has unsafe quality record
Established relationship with out-of-network provider for ongoing treatment
network_exceptions.how_to_request: Call insurance and ask for a network exception or gap exception
network_exceptions.documentation: Get letter from doctor explaining why exception is needed

surprise_billing_protections.no_surprises_act: Federal law protecting you from surprise bills
surprise_billing_protections.your_cost: You only pay in-network cost-sharing amounts
surprise_billing_protections.what_to_do_if_billed: Dispute the bill; you should not owe balance billing

tax_advantages: Withdrawals for medical expenses are tax-free
using_health_savings_accounts.strategy: Use HSA funds for current medical expenses or save for future healthcare costs in retirement

healthcare_fsa.use_it_or_lose_it: Must use funds by end of plan year (some plans allow carryover or grace period)
healthcare_fsa.no_hdhp_required: Can use with any health plan

key_vocabulary.definition: The amount you pay each month for insurance coverage
The amount you pay before insurance starts covering costs
A fixed amount you pay for a covered service
Your percentage share of costs after meeting the deductible
The most you pay in a year for covered services
Insurance approval needed before certain services are covered
The doctors, hospitals, and facilities your plan has contracted with
A formal request for insurance to reconsider a denial

action_items.action: Review your Summary of Benefits and Coverage
action_items.why: Understand what your plan covers and what you will pay

action_items.action: Check if your doctors are in-network
Know your plan's prior authorization requirements
action_items.why: Avoid unexpected bills for services not pre-approved
You may need documentation for appeals or disputes
Many appeals succeed, and it is your right
